author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Clergy Preach Faith in the Covid Vaccine to Doubters
description: With widespread immunity essential to ending the pandemic, priests, imams, rabbis and swamis are successfully urging their congregations to get the shots. Many people trust them more than they trust health officials.
content: During a recent Sunday service at the Gathering Place, an evangelical church in Orlando, Fla., the Rev. Gabriel Salguero focused his sermon on the Covid-19 vaccine, and the fear and suspicion that his largely Latino congregation clutches so tightly.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Case for the Subway’
description: It built New York City. One writer on why, no matter the cost, the city must rebuild it to survive.
content: Long before it became an archaic and filthy symbol of everything wrong with America’s broken cities, the New York subway was a marvel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: The Swag Must Go On: Hollywood’s Pandemic Oscar Campaign
description: “There is a why-are-we-even-doing-this feeling,” one industry insider said of jockeying for nominations, to be announced on Monday.
content: LOS ANGELES — As a potential Oscar nominee for film editing, William Goldenberg should be feeling dizzy right about now. So many tastemaker cocktail parties to attend. So many panel discussions to participate in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: How the Pandemic Has Transformed the Idea of Home
description: Lockdowns and restrictions have forced millions of people around the world to adapt to their spaces and exist within the confines of four walls. We asked readers how their relationship to their homes was affected.
content: Before the pandemic began, your home may have merely been a place to sleep. Or maybe it was a precious escape from the hustle and bustle of the outside world. But now, a year after the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus outbreak a pandemic, home has taken on an entirely new meaning. A year of lockdowns and various restrictions have forced millions of people around the world to adapt to their spaces and exist within the confines of four walls. Many could no longer afford to pay rent and subsequently lost their homes, their sense of security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Astor
title: The last living man of the Juma people in Brazil has died from Covid-19.
description: Aruká Juma saw his Amazon tribe dwindle to just a handful of individuals during his lifetime.
content: Aruká Juma saw his Amazon tribe dwindle to just a handful of individuals during his lifetime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Blue Ivy Carter, Beyoncé’s daughter, wins her first Grammy.
description: The mother-daughter duo won in the best music video category for “Brown Skin Girl,” which appears on the visual album “Black Is King.”
content: At only 9 years old, Beyoncé’s oldest daughter, Blue Ivy Carter, is already starting to follow in her parents’ footsteps, winning her first Grammy for her role in the music video for “Brown Skin Girl.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Dropping mask mandates, even as vaccinations speed up, is ‘risky business,’ Dr. Fauci warns.
description: An increasing number of states have drop mask requirements and dining restrictions at the one-year mark of the pandemic.
content: With millions of Americans vaccinated and states dropping mask and dining restrictions at the one-year mark of the pandemic, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci warned on Sunday against loosening restrictions prematurely, despite the recent week-over-week decreases in new coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: New Suitor May Enter Fray for Tribune Publishing
description: A Maryland hotel magnate who had a deal to buy The Baltimore Sun is now weighing a bid for all of Tribune’s newspapers that could thwart a hedge fund’s plan.
content: A deal that would reshape the American newspaper industry has run into complications just one month after an agreement was reached, according to three people with knowledge of the matter. As a result, the New York hedge fund Alden Global Capital may have to fend off a new suitor for Tribune Publishing, the chain that owns major metropolitan dailies across the country, including The Chicago Tribune, The Daily News and The Baltimore Sun, the people said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrienne Gaffney
title: Enjoy a Book Tour, In Your Living Room
description: Once a limited-capacity event, now a writer conversation can be enjoyed from the exclusivity of your living room.
content: Authors releasing books in the past year have experienced a radically altered literary landscape — perhaps most significantly, they have lost the ability to venture out on the standard book tour, which typically includes a series of readings and talks across the country. While many book lovers yearn for the days of big-name events or cozy chats at indie bookstores, others are enjoying access for the first time. For those who do not live in the major cities and college towns that tend to be destinations for top writers, the pandemic has offered them the ability to experience these events online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Payments Start-Up Stripe Surges to $95 Billion Valuation
description: The company has benefited in the pandemic as people turn to online shopping. It is now the most valuable start-up in the U.S.
content: The payments company Stripe is worth $95 billion after a new round of funding, making it the most valuable start-up in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Rick Pitino Forges a New Path to the Tournament With Iona
description: Pitino got used to making runs to the N.C.A.A. tournament with big-name programs, until Louisville fired him in 2017. Iona gave him a chance to find another way in.
content: ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. — The old Atlantic City Boardwalk Hall, with its Renaissance-style architecture, its grand arched roof and the world’s largest pipe organ, is a fitting platform for a final act. And so, there was Rick Pitino late Saturday afternoon, with only family members and friends in the cavernous arena, stalking the sidelines in a dapper navy suit, waving his rolled-up notes around like a maestro conducting an orchestra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Piers Morgan Can’t Wait to Bring the Worst of America Home
description: British TV executives see opportunity — and money to be made — in bringing American cable-style clashes to their screens.
content: When Piers Morgan stormed off the set of “Good Morning Britain” last week as a Black colleague chided him for “trashing” Meghan Markle, it felt like a familiar American scene: a tone-deaf old-timer getting swept aside by an anti-racist younger generation, as the culture of media changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cierra S. Queen, Benjamin Guggenheim and Danielle Ivory
title: Fewer than half of states are giving vaccine access to U.S. Postal Service workers.
description: The agency has been under extraordinary stress in the pandemic,  and thousands of its workers across the country have contracted the coronavirus. More than 150 have died.
content: Beleaguered in the pandemic and thrust into the spotlight by the 2020 election, the United States Postal Service now finds itself competing for its share of the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Zack Snyder’s Rough and Tumble Ride With ‘Justice League’
description: The director digs into his exit from the original version of the epic and what led to his edit, the Snyder Cut, which HBO Max will release Thursday. “Am I a provocateur? A little bit.”
content: Even superhero movies can have dual identities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, John Ismay and Steven Lee Myers
title: Biden Goals Converge in Asia: Rebuilding Alliances and Countering China
description: A flurry of diplomacy, which includes talks in Tokyo and Seoul, is a prelude to the administration’s first in-person meeting with top Chinese envoys.
content: WASHINGTON — Two ambitions lie at the center of President Biden’s foreign policy agenda: rebuilding ties with frustrated allies and assembling a united front on China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Bloodshed and defiance in Myanmar.
content: At least 51 people were fatally shot over the weekend, but the nationwide protest movement against Myanmar’s military coup a month and a half ago shows no sign of waning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: Women’s Basketball Makes Room for New Stars, and New Contenders
description: The usual elites are still great, but the rest of the college field has a real shot to win the championship this year. Star power isn’t concentrated at the top anymore.
content: There are few more compelling diversions than N.C.A.A. tournament basketball, and after the postseason was canceled last March because of the coronavirus pandemic, plenty of the best players in women’s basketball are hungry for the bright lights of the big stage. Their passion for the game will, at least for the next few weeks, become our own as we become immersed in the bracket’s glories and heartbreaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: New York City marked a year since its first virus death with a virtual memorial.
description: The ceremony was streamed online on the city’s website and on social media platforms at 7:45 p.m. Eastern. Survivors can submit the names and photographs of the loved ones they lost to the virus.
content: One year after its first coronavirus-related death, New York City held a virtual memorial event on Sunday honoring the tens of thousands of New Yorkers who have died of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Days of Killings and Defiance in Myanmar, With Neither Side Relenting
description: At least 51 people were fatally shot over the weekend, but the nationwide protest movement shows no sign of waning.
content: Soldiers and police officers shot and killed at least 51 people in Myanmar over the weekend, as they pressed their campaign of attrition against protesters who have defied them in cities and towns across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Long-Lost Mosaic From a ‘Floating Palace’ of Caligula Returns Home
description: A 2,000-year-old artifact that had ended up in the home of a Manhattan antiquities dealer is now in an Italian museum.
content: NEMI, Italy — If stones could speak, the mosaic unveiled recently at an archaeological museum just south of Rome would have quite the tale to tell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Baylor Is the Top Seed in a Region of Heavyweights
description: North Carolina and Villanova are among the teams that will try to challenge the Bears in the South Region.
content: In spite of a loss to Oklahoma State on Friday night, Baylor could find itself in a fight for the title as it leans on three starting guards: Jared Butler, MaCio Teague and Davion Mitchell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Flory Jagoda, Keeper of Sephardic Music Tradition, Dies at 97
description: A charismatic musician, she sang and wrote songs that linked her to Jewish ancestors who lived in Spain until their expulsion in 1492.
content: To Flory Jagoda, the language, rhythms and joys of the Sephardic Jewish music she sang and wrote connected her to her beloved nona — her grandmother — who lived in the small mountain village of Vlasenica in the former Yugoslavia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Vowed to Make Climate ‘Essential’ to Foreign Policy. The Reality Is Harder.
description: So far, repairing alliances and restoring friendships seem to be taking precedence.
content: WASHINGTON — In late January, President Biden pledged to make combating climate change “an essential element of U.S. foreign policy and national security,” appointing a high-powered global climate envoy and salting the State Department with climate expertise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, Middleweight Champion of the 1980s, Dies at 66
description: One of the most formidable boxers of his era, Hagler defended his title 12 times before losing to Sugar Ray Leonard in a 1987 split decision.
content: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, who became one of boxing’s greatest middleweight champions, wielding awesome punching power while shrugging off opponents’ blows, died on Saturday in New Hampshire. He was 66 and lived in Bartlett, N.H.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Ireland suspends use of the AstraZeneca vaccine, citing blood clot reports.
description: Major public health agencies have offered reassurances, noting that millions of people have received the vaccine without problems and that no causative link has been found between the vaccine and clots.
content: Ireland suspended use of the Covid-19 vaccine by Oxford-AstraZeneca on Sunday, citing reports of unusual blood clotting problems among people who recently received the shots in Norway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Daniel Berehulak
title: On Mexico’s Border With U.S.,Desperation as Migrant Traffic Piles Up
description: Mexico is struggling to deal with a new wave of migrants expelled from the U.S. while even more come north hoping to cross. Shelters that were empty four months ago are now having to turn many away.
content: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — The migrants’ hopes have been drummed up by human smugglers who promise that President Biden’s administration will welcome them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Policing at Sarah Everard Vigil in London Faces Official Scrutiny
description: The killing of Ms. Everard, 33, has prompted soul-searching over violence against women in Britain. And the breaking up of a banned vigil in her memory has focused criticism on London’s police.
content: LONDON — The mayor of London and the British cabinet minister responsible for policing called Sunday for an independent inquiry into how the city’s main police force broke up a vigil for Sarah Everard, the 33-year-old marketing executive whose killing has sparked a reckoning over violence against women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Powerful German Editor, Accused of Misconduct, Takes Leave
description: Julian Reichelt, editor of the tabloid-style Bild, denied accusations by female employees but stepped aside while the newspaper’s owner conducts an internal investigation.
content: The editor in chief of Bild, Europe’s largest newspaper and an influential force in German politics and society, has taken a leave of absence while a law firm conducts an investigation into accusations made against him, the publication’s owner said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Grammys fashion goes live and over-the-top.
description: Stars like Doja Cat and Noah Cyrus went for looks that were anything but restrained at the first quasi-live mega-awards red carpet since the start of the pandemic.
content: It’s been awhile since we’ve actually seen the strutting, preening, over-the-top fashion show that is an awards season red carpet. After all, even before the pandemic hit, there was some rethinking going on, as female performers in particular started demanding not to be simply reduced to what they wore. So when the Grammy powers that be announced they were going to figure out how to bring the whole shebang back — well, it was not entirely clear what that would mean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim and Lila Barth
title: The Missing Hours: 7 Students on Losing a Year of After-School Activities
description: No football, no dance, no Y.M.C.A.
content: From 3 p.m. to 6 p.m. That block of time, between the end of classes and the beginning of dinner, were for millions of teenagers everywhere the golden hours of the day. They provided a release from the pressures of school or an escape from a stressful home. It was a time for friendship and fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Illinois Takes Midwest and Big Ten Title
description: And Houston, the No. 2 seed, should rely on its all-star defense to tamp down opponents as it progresses through the tournament.
content: It has been a long while, but Illinois has shown it can still field awfully good basketball teams. Now the Fighting Illini would just like some credit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Netflix Tests a Clampdown on Password Sharing
description: The company said a feature was being tested with a limited number of users, a move that might signal a broader crackdown on the common practice of password sharing among family and friends.
content: Want to watch “The Queen’s Gambit” or “Lupin”? If you’ve been borrowing a Netflix password from a family member or friend, you may now have to pay up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Here Comes the Stimulus Cash
description: Biden’s economic relief package has arrived.
content: Good morning. Millions of Americans will receive their stimulus payments any minute now, as the American Rescue Plan is up and running. Here’s what else you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Jett
title: Yo-Yo Ma gives a surprise cello concert at a Massachusetts vaccination site.
description: He used the 15-minute observation period after receiving his second dose to play “Ave Maria” and Bach’s Prelude in G Major.
content: The world-renowned cellist Yo-Yo Ma gave a surprise concert on Saturday at a vaccination site in Massachusetts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: You Probably Need New Running Shoes. Here’s How to Upgrade.
description: Look at the bottom of your sneakers for clues as to when you need a new pair. And trust your local running store to help you find the right fit.
content: If you run, you’re a runner. And if you’re a runner, especially one who has hit the pavement more in the past year, there’s a good chance you need to upgrade your running shoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Administration Directs FEMA to Help Shelter Migrant Children
description: The agency will help provide basic care as criticism mounts over the treatment of the increasing number of young migrants who have filled detention facilities at the southwest border.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is directing the Federal Emergency Management Agency to assist in processing an increasing number of children and teenagers who have filled detention facilities at the southwest border, as criticism mounts over the treatment of young migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: 10 Years Ago, the Village Was Erased
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 14, 2021.
content: “Our ancestors lived in this village 1,000 years ago. There were disasters then, too. Each time the people stayed. They rebuilt and stayed. Rebuilt and stayed. I feel an obligation to continue what my ancestors started. I don’t want to lose my hometown.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Which vaccines are available in the U.S. now, and which may be coming?
description: Two vaccines are in wide use, a third is getting there, and there may soon be more alternatives. Here is a rundown.
content: About 20 percent of the U.S. population has received at least one Covid-19 vaccine shot as the pace of inoculations in the United States sharply climbs. Here is a look at the vaccines that have been authorized by the Food and Drug Administration and where some other vaccine candidates stand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Cook Persian Food and Practice Meditation
description: This week, celebrate St. Patrick’s Day, listen to Shakespeare or make some art.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: One Year in a Pandemic: Your Weekend Briefing
description: A special edition looking at a year of living in disruption and pain.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Drew Brees Retires, His Focus on the Details Until the End
description: Brees, who won seven division titles as the Saints’ quarterback, including the most recent four, retired after 20 seasons with the most completions and passing yards in N.F.L. history.
content: Every great quarterback has a defining characteristic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shauna Farnell
title: To Reach His Dream, This Teen Will Have to Touch the Sky
description: Brian Rice is a fearless 16-year-old who dreams of becoming the first African-American snowboarder to compete in the Olympics.
content: COPPER MOUNTAIN, Colo. — Like his mother, Brian Rice has played just about every sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Undefeated Gonzaga Sits Atop West
description: Iowa is the No. 2 seed for the region, hoping to extend its reach past the Sweet 16 for the first time since 1999.
content: Gonzaga is the first team to enter the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament undefeated since Kentucky in 2014-15, and the Zags have a legitimate shot to become the first undefeated national champion since Indiana finished 32-0 in the 1975-76 season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: N.C.A.A. Tournament: Things to Know Going Into Selection Sunday
description: The field of 68 teams for the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament will include 37 at-large bids and 31 automatic qualifiers.
content: One year after the pandemic-induced cancellation of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament resulted in a $600 million decline in the N.C.A.A.’s revenue for 2020, March Madness is back in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Democrats Repent for Bill Clinton
description: In the last decade, the party and the former president himself have been forced to admit the failures of his administration.
content: Bill Clinton was a charismatic Southern governor — extraordinarily at ease around nonwhite people and possessing a preternatural social sensibility — who became a remarkable president. He knew how to make people feel positive and hopeful, to make them feel seen and heard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany Launches Election Year With Losses for Merkel’s Party in Two States
description: Voters choosing regional governments in southwestern states punished the conservative party of Chancellor Angela Merkel after a series of scandals.
content: BERLIN — Voters in two southwestern German states punished Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative party in regional elections on Sunday, early results showed, turning from the Christian Democrats in record numbers amid the coronavirus pandemic and a growing scandal over lawmakers who accepted kickbacks for selling masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Nicole Perlroth
title: White House Weighs New Cybersecurity Approach After Failure to Detect Hacks
description: The intelligence agencies missed massive intrusions by Russia and China, forcing the administration and Congress to look for solutions, including closer partnership with private industry.
content: WASHINGTON — The sophisticated hacks pulled off by Russia and China against a broad array of government and industrial targets in the United States — and the failure of the intelligence agencies to detect them — are driving the Biden administration and Congress to rethink how the nation should protect itself from growing cyberthreats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: It’s Pi Day, a time for pie whether it’s filled with apple or key lime, mushroom or chicken.
content: Good morning. It is Pi Day, for those who delight in numbers and pay attention to such things: 3.14, a mathematical constant, the ratio of a circle’s circumference to its diameter. Also a day for untrammeled truth: Everyone loves pie, even those who prefer cake. (And it’s a day to check your clocks. Time sprang forward an hour last night in accordance with Daylight Saving Time.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Winter
title: Our Autofiction Fixation
description: Why do we assume that a work of literary fiction must be based on its author’s life?
content: In February 2020, at a book party in a Brooklyn brownstone, a smiling stranger walked up to me. “We have something in common, you know,” she said. “We conceived our children without having sex.” My memory of the exchange then goes blank for a moment — I must have spluttered some confused pleasantry in response — but it quickly emerged that she had read my first novel, which explores its protagonist’s struggles with infertility, and drawn the conclusion that I myself had undergone I.V.F., as she had.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Parish
title: Go Fly a (Newspaper) Kite!
description: With your feet on the ground, you’re a bird in flight, with your fist holding tight to the string of your homemade kite.
content: Easy to build, simple to fly, the diamond kite — two sticks crossed and bound together, covered by a diamond-shaped piece of paper — is the most recognized kite shape in the Western world. A woodcut image from the 1600s is the oldest known reference to the diamond kite. And all it requires is a couple of sticks, some newspaper and string.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: ‘A saving grace’: Stimulus payments begin to arrive in bank accounts.
description: More payments will be sent out in the next few weeks, with some arriving by mail as checks or debit cards.
content: Stimulus payments have started to land in Americans’ bank accounts, just days after President Biden signed a $1.9 trillion pandemic rescue bill into law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Colorado Snowstorm Knocks Out Power to Thousands and Snarls Travel
description: The storm, which brought heavy, wet snow to parts of Colorado and Wyoming, resulted in road closings, canceled flights and downed trees and power lines.
content: DENVER — A snowstorm sweeping through Colorado and Wyoming on Sunday was expected to bring as much as four feet of snow to some parts of the region, and has left nearly 30,000 people without power in Colorado.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: They Get Smashed at Parties
description: Philip K. Chow makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Philip K. Chow, a civil engineer in New York City, makes his New York Times Crossword debut with a puzzle that taught me something that I did not know. You can’t ask for much more than that, except maybe for a puzzle made of dark chocolate. But I digress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aidan Gardiner
title: For families in medicine, it’s been a year of fear and loss.
description: Gabrielle Dawn Luna sees her father in every patient she treats.
content: Gabrielle Dawn Luna sees her father in every patient she treats.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘When They Have Finished, My Husband Hands Them a 20’
description: Getting some help shoveling, delving into a childhood altercation and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani and Raphael Minder
title: Italians prepare for a widespread lockdown on Monday.
description: The circulation of a more contagious variant of the coronavirus, combined with a slow vaccine rollout, led to a 15 percent increase in cases nationally last week.
content: Italians enjoyed the last weekend outdoors before three-quarters of the population goes into a strict lockdown on Monday, when the government puts in place restrictive measures to fight the rise in coronavirus infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 15, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: Youth sports have seen their share of virus outbreaks, but for many the benefits outweigh the risks.
description: A year after the coronavirus crisis first closed athletic fields and darkened school gyms, students, parents, coaches and officials have struggled to navigate the challenges of youth sports, weighing concerns about transmitting the virus against the social, emotional and sometimes financial benefits of competition.
content: A year after the coronavirus crisis first closed athletic fields and darkened school gyms, students, parents, coaches and officials have struggled to navigate the challenges of youth sports, weighing concerns about transmitting the virus against the social, emotional and sometimes financial benefits of competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: 2021 Grammys Winners: The Full List
description: The 63rd annual awards were held in Los Angeles on Sunday. Here is the full list of winners.
content: The 63rd annual Grammy Awards were held in Los Angeles on Sunday, and the show was hosted by Trevor Noah. Here are the highlights:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Well-Earned Walk: Luis Guillorme Trots to First After 22 Pitches
description: After falling behind 0-2, a Mets infielder added another unbelievable feat to an unusual résumé. He might have set an unofficial record.
content: It was only an exhibition, so nothing from the Mets’ 7-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals on Sunday will count as more than an amusing oddity. But the Mets’ Luis Guillorme did something that just might be unprecedented: He saw 22 pitches in a single turn at the plate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: March Madness Arrives: 68-Team N.C.A.A. Tournament Field Revealed
description: Gonzaga, Baylor, Illinois and Michigan were awarded No. 1 seeds as the bracket was revealed on Selection Sunday.
content: When the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament bracket was announced on Sunday night, it was in keeping with sports during the pandemic: stripped down, masked up and written hopefully in pencil.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 14, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 14, 2020.
content: An attribution attached to a quote with an article on Page 10 about New York’s cultural landscape in the moments before it shut down in March 2020 misspells the given name of an actress. She is Brittney Mack, not Brittsney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Has 1,000 More Troops in Afghanistan Than It Disclosed
description: The undercount complicates President Biden’s decision on carrying out a complete withdrawal by May 1, as his administration tries to jump-start peace talks.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Facing a high-stakes choice and running out of time to make it, the Biden administration is wrestling with whether to follow through with a full withdrawal in the next seven weeks of the 2,500 American troops still in Afghanistan — except, as it turns out, that number is actually around 3,500.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Carmel Quinn, Irish Singer and Storyteller, Dies at 95
description: A hit on the television variety-show circuit of the 1950s and ’60s, she also sang to packed crowds for many years at Carnegie Hall for St. Patrick’s Day
content: Carmel Quinn, a blue-eyed, flame-haired Irish singer and storyteller who packed Carnegie Hall on St. Patrick’s Day for a quarter-century and regaled her audiences with tunes and tales from the Old Country, died on March 6 at her home in Leonia, N.J. She was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Michigan Leads East After Falling Short in Big Ten Tournament
description: Right behind the Wolverines: No. 2 Alabama, which must contend with Rick Pitino’s Iona team in the first round.
content: When Michigan hired Juwan Howard, one of the stars of its “Fab Five” team from the early ’90s who went on to a long N.B.A. career, as its coach in May 2019, he didn’t have head coaching experience on his résumé.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Small Piece of the Stimulus Has Ambitious Aim of Saving Mothers’ Lives
description: The expansion of Medicaid is an effort to address the highest maternal death rate among wealthy nations.
content: It’s easy to overlook amid the hundreds of pages of the $1.9 trillion stimulus plan President Biden signed into law Thursday, but a short section aims to combat America’s maternal mortality crisis by expanding health coverage for new mothers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: A new study suggests 3 feet, not 6 feet, is sufficient distance for school students, with mask-wearing and other safety measures kept in place.
description: The new study, published last week in the journal Clinical Infectious Diseases, suggests public schools may be able to reopen safely for in-person instruction as long as children maintain three feet of distance between them, and with other mitigation measures maintained, such as wearing masks.
content: School shutdowns have been a divisive topic since the pandemic erupted, and a new study has ignited debate over the six-foot rule of social distancing and whether it can be relaxed in classroom settings, which would ease the way for children to return to schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Alan Feuer
title: Police Shrugged Off the Proud Boys, Until They Attacked the Capitol
description: Two Proud Boys accused of leading a mob to Congress followed a bloody path to get there. Law enforcement did little to stop them.
content: A protester was burning an American flag outside the 2016 Republican convention in Cleveland when Joseph Biggs rushed to attack. Jumping a police line, he ripped the man’s shirt off and “started pounding,” he boasted that night in an online video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: ‘Think of vaccines as part of God’s plan’: Clergy members urge the hesitant to get shots.
description: Thousands of clergy members from a cross-section of faiths — imams, rabbis, priests, swamis — are trying to coax hesitant Americans to get vaccinated against Covid-19.
content: Thousands of clergy members from a cross-section of faiths — imams, rabbis, priests, swamis — are trying to coax hesitant Americans to get vaccinated against Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Besha Rodell
title: Momofuku Seiobo, in Sydney, Will Close in June
description: Opened by David Chang in 2011, the restaurant served Caribbean-inspired food from the chef Paul Carmichael.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Momofuku Seiobo, the acclaimed restaurant that David Chang opened in 2011 in a back hallway of the glitzy Star Casino in Sydney, will close at the end of June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and J. David Goodman
title: As Cuomo Reels, Pleas for Political Support Come From His Vaccine Czar
description: Larry Schwartz, whom Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo put in charge of the state’s vaccination efforts, called some county executives about support for the governor.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — At the height of the pandemic, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called upon some of his most trusted emissaries to return to the fold to help coordinate the state’s coronavirus response, including Larry Schwartz, his former top aide who is now leading New York’s vaccination efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: In Rage Over Sarah Everard Killing, ‘Women’s Bargain’ Is Put on Notice
description: The “Reclaim These Streets” movement in Britain asks why the police demand sacrifices of women rather than forcing men to change to end violence. “It makes my stomach rot,” one organizer said.
content: Perhaps it was because pandemic lockdowns have left women clinging to whatever is left of their access to public space. Perhaps it was because after more than three years of the #MeToo movement, the police and society are still telling women to sacrifice their liberties to purchase a little temporary safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Online, Simon Rattle Gives a Preview of His Future in Munich
description: The British conductor will take the helm of the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra in 2023. But he got a head start with three livestreamed concerts.
content: In an evening of back-to-back concerts recently, the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra played music that asks the big questions: Is there a God? What are we to make of war and death? How do we perceive the world around us?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Grammys 2021: How to Watch, Time and Streaming
description: A guide to everything you need to know for the 63rd annual Grammy Awards on Sunday night.
content: [Follow our live coverage of the 2021 Grammys and winners list.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jackie Snow
title: Livestreaming, Still Niche, Grows as a Tool for Retailers
description: Amazon Live is a prominent example of how interactive video shopping, popularized by TV networks like QVC, has moved online.
content: Matt Granite had been working for years as a consumer journalist filming segments that were syndicated on American television stations and sharing additional videos on his YouTube channel, The Deal Guy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Berkman
title: Korean TV’s Unlikely Star: Subway Sandwiches
description: The sandwich chain’s aggressive use of product placement has made it a ubiquitous presence on the country’s television shows.
content: In an episode of the Korean television show “The K2,” which takes place in a world of fugitives and bodyguards, a man is being treated with a defibrillator when he enters into a dream state. On the fringe of death, he recalls taking a past love to a Subway restaurant and to a park for a picnic, where he gently feeds her a sandwich and soft drink with the Subway logo facing the camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Erin Schaff
title: Tiny Town, Big Decision: What Are We Willing to Pay to Fight the Rising Sea?
description: On the Outer Banks, homeowners in Avon are confronting a tax increase of almost 50 percent to protect their homes, the only road into town, and perhaps the community’s very existence.
content: AVON, N.C. — Bobby Outten, a county manager in the Outer Banks, delivered two pieces of bad news at a recent public meeting. Avon, a town with a few hundred full-time residents, desperately needed at least $11 million to stop its main road from washing away. And to help pay for it, Dare County wanted to increase Avon’s property taxes, in some cases by almost 50 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Mixed-Up Brothers of Bogotá
description: How two sets of twins, scrambled at birth, had their lives changed in an instant.
content: How two sets of twins, scrambled at birth, had their lives changed in an instant.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Special Ops Became the Solution to Everything
description: America’s elite forces have solved a lot of national-security problems, and they’ve grown and grown. But the country’s reliance on them is becoming a problem in itself.
content: America’s elite forces have solved a lot of national-security problems, and they’ve grown and grown. But the country’s reliance on them is becoming a problem in itself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Case for New York's Subways
description: It built New York City. One writer on why, no matter the cost, the city must rebuild it to survive.
content: It built New York City. One writer on why, no matter the cost, the city must rebuild it to survive.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Culture Warped Pop, for Good
description: How chart-topping songs changed without us even noticing.
content: How chart-topping songs changed without us even noticing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Hundreds March in Louisville a Year After Breonna Taylor’s Death
description: On the anniversary of her death, the family of Breonna Taylor rallied in Louisville, Ky., on Saturday alongside supporters and the families of several other people of color who were fatally shot by police around the country.
content: On the anniversary of her death, the family of Breonna Taylor rallied in Louisville, Ky., on Saturday alongside supporters and the families of several other people of color who were fatally shot by police around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: At Least 51 People Killed Over the Weekend in Myanmar Protests
description: Demonstrators clashed with security forces throughout Myanmar on Sunday, a month and a half into steady nationwide protests in defiance of the military coup on Feb. 1 and the ousting of civilian leaders.
content: Demonstrators clashed with security forces throughout Myanmar on Sunday, a month and a half into steady nationwide protests in defiance of the military coup on Feb. 1 and the ousting of civilian leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is Too Much Choice Ruining Us?
description: Readers mostly agree with Paul Krugman that it’s an unwanted feature of modern life.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Remembering the Holocaust: ‘A Necessary Discomfort’
description: The Museum of Jewish Heritage discusses the deportation case of a former Nazi. Also: New York bagels versus California bagels; that second fridge.
